intro: Tephroseris fuscata, commonly known as the black sand plant, is a species of flowering plant native to the southern United States and parts of Mexico. It belongs to the Acanthaceae family and is characterized by its upright growth habit and lance-shaped leaves. The plant produces small, tubular flowers that are typically pink or purple in color, which bloom during the summer months. Tephroseris fuscata thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, making it a suitable candidate for rock gardens and xeriscaping. Its resilience to drought and ability to grow in poor soil conditions contribute to its popularity among gardeners in arid regions.
